item.title: Generic Factorization
item.description: Note This page is not based off the curriculum, and therefore is not required. Vieta’s formulas relate the coefficients of polynomials to sums and products of its roots. All the other methods of factorization can be derived from these formulas. Quadratics For quadratics, the polynomial is $$s P(x)=a_2x^2+a_1x+a_0 $$e , and the sum and product can derived from the formula: $$s r_1+r_2=\frac{-a_1}{a_2} $$e $$s r_1r_2=\frac{a_0}{a_2} $$e Changing the variable names results in something more familliar: $$s P(x)=ax^2+bx+c $$e $$s r_1+r_2=\frac{-b}{a} $$e $$s r_1r_2=\frac{c}{a} $$e

item.title: Multiplication of Polynomials
item.description: Multiplication of binomials follow this rule: $$s(a+b)(c+d)=ac+ad+bc+bd$$e This can be easily remembered by using the FOIL method: Multiply the first terms: $sac$e Multiply the outer terms: $sad$e Multiply the inner terms: $sbc$e Multiply the last terms: $sbd$e Example $$s(3x-1)(4-2x)$$e $$s12x-6x^2-4+2x$$e $$s-6x^2+14x-4$$e Note The content below is a *joke*. item.title: Binomial Expansion
item.description: The binomial theorem describes how to expand powers of binomials. Example Using the theorem, $s(x+2)^3$e is $s8 + 12 x + 6 x^2 + x^3$e . The $sr$e th coefficient for the $sn$e th is $sn\choose r$e , pronounced “n choose r”. Example The 4th coefficient of $s(3x+8)^6$e is $s6\choose 3$e $s(3x)^38^3$e $s=276480x^3$e

item.title: Factor Perfect Square Trinomials and Difference of Squares
item.description: Difference of Squares The difference of squares formula can be applied in many contexts (it’s often hiding in the equation!). $$sa^2-b^2=(a+b)(a-b)$$e Example $$s4x^2-16$$e $$s=(2x-4)^2$$e Perfect Square Trinomials Perfect square trinomials are derived by expanding equations like $s(a+b)^2$e . $$sa^2+2ab+b^2=(a+b)^2$$e $$sa^2-2ab+b^2=(a-b)^2$$e Example $$s4x^2+20x+25$$e $$s=(2x+5)^2$$e

item.title: Factor Quadratics 2
item.description: To factor trinomials in the form $sax^2+bx+c$e : $$sy+z=ac$$e $$syz=b$$e $$sax^2+bx+c$$e $$s=ax^2+yx+zx+c$$e Example $$s6x^2+17x+12$$e Because $syz=ac$e , $sy+z=b$e , $sy=8$e and $sz=9$e . $$s=6x^2+8x+9x+12$$e $$s=2x(3x+4)+3(3x+4)$$e Then, factor by grouping. $$s=(2x+3)(3x+4)$$e

item.title: Factor Quadratics
item.description: To factor trinomials in the form $sx^2+bx+c$e : $$sy+z=c$$e $$syz=b$$e $$sx^2+bx+c$$e $$s=(x+y)(x+z)$$e Example $$sx^4+11x^2+30$$e $$s=(x^2+6)(x^2+5)$$e

item.title: Common Factoring
item.description: Factoring is the opposite of exapanding (what we did so far). To factor a polynomial, group the polynomials by the GCF: $$s8x^2y^2-12x^4y$$e $$s4x^2y(2y^2-3x^2)$$e Example Remember: a GCF does not have to be a monomial. In this case, it is $sx+2$e . $$sa(x+2)+b(x+2)$$e $$s=(a+b)(x+2)$$e You can also factor by grouping terms with a common factor: Example $$s2am+8a+4m+16$$e $$s=(4+m)(2a+4)$$e $$s=2(a+2)(m+4)$$e

item.title: Special Products
item.description: When squaring a binomial, the result becomes: $$s(a+b)^2$$e $$s=a^2+2ab+b^2$$e $$s(a-b)^2$$e $$s=a^2-2ab+b^2$$e Example $$s(3x-2y)^2$$e $$s=9x^2-12xy+4y^2$$e
